scene.name: intro
scene.line: Damn. It's almost totally intact. I thought it would have been destroyed.

scene.name: destroyed-by-what
scene.line: When the mine flooded, I mean. It looks so fragile, doesn't it?

scene.name: what-is-this-place
scene.line: It's a recording studio, basically. Kind of thrown together, but ...

scene.name: archivists-first-time
scene.line: When this mine was active, a couple of folk music archivists spent time here recording miners' songs. Really academic, ivory tower types. None of the miners really talked to them much.
So they stayed at the margins, observed, took notes, and then sometimes they'd get someone on a lunch break to sing into their microphone.
Then I guess the power company got some kind of interest in the project, and gave the archivists some coal scrip tokens to pay the miners with for their songs.

scene.name: archivists-again
scene.line: This is where the archivists would record, and I guess then they'd sequester themselves down by that tape deck we found, to listen to the recorded songs.

scene.name: questions
scene.option: Did you ever come down here?
What do you think the archivists were after?

scene.name: did-shannon-come-here
scene.line: Yeah, I came here with my parents once or twice. They used to play music here, even when those archivists weren't around. It was a nice setup; kinda rickety, kinda dangerous, I guess, but ... I don't know. It had a good energy. It was warm, sometimes.

scene.name: what-were-archivists-after
scene.line: Data, I guess? Comparing intonation, subject matter, diction ... you know, all those little details that no one really thinks about when they listen to music. Yeah, academics are great at that stuff. Let's get out of here.
